question: When does the General Head Boundary (GHB) result in inflow to an aquifer (i.e., acts as source), and when in outflow (i.e., acts as sink)? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. The GHB can switch between source and sink depending on head difference, and becomes inactive when heads are equal.
error: ❌ Review the role of head differences. The GHB acts as a source or sink depending on which head is higher.

question: What happens to the boundary flux Q_B if the conductance C_B is set to zero or extremely high? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Well reasoned. A zero conductance blocks flow, and high conductance amplifies the flux and head coupling.
error: ❌ Check the influence of the conductance value on the head difference and resulting flow.

question: How does increasing conductance C_B influence the sensitivity of flux to aquifer head changes? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Excellent. Higher conductance enhances sensitivity and mimics fixed-head behavior.
error: ❌ Revisit how conductance affects the slope of the Q-h relationship and system responsiveness.

question: Why might a modeler choose a GHB over a defined(fixed)-head condition? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. The GHB is flexible and suitable for simulating dynamic inflow/outflow at semi-permeable boundaries.
error: ❌ Think about the physical situations GHBs are designed to represent and how they differ from other boundary types.

question: How does the slope of the $Q_B$–$h_{aq}$ plot respond to increasing conductance $C_B$? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Exactly. A higher $C_B$ results in a steeper response of $Q_B$ to head changes.
error: ❌ Recall that $Q_B$ is directly proportional to $C_B$ times the head difference.

question: What is true when $h_{aq} = H_B$? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Equal heads mean no driving force — no flow occurs.
error: ❌ Review the condition when $H_B = h_{aq}$. There is no head gradient to cause flow.
